summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (USAFLS) staff discussing Jeffrey Epstein's case. It reveals internal discussions about Epstein seeking to reduce his sentence, the identification of additional victims, and a directive to cease negotiations with him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the email chain; a defendant seeking to reduce his sentence in a plea deal.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Mentioned as being clear, along with 'Wand', that the office is no longer negotiating with Epstein.

persons.name: Wand
persons.context: Mentioned as being clear, along with 'Alex', that the office is no longer negotiating with Epstein.

connections.description: Both are staff at the U.S. Attorney's Office (USAFLS) who jointly issued a directive regarding the Epstein case.
Alex, as part of the U.S. Attorney's Office, is involved in the prosecution and decision-making regarding Epstein's plea deal.
Wand, as part of the U.S. Attorney's Office, is involved in the prosecution and decision-making regarding Epstein's plea deal.

events.title: Internal Email Discussion on Epstein Plea
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office staff exchange emails discussing Epstein's request to reduce his sentence, the identification of more victims, and a directive to stop negotiations.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was seeking to reduce his sentence ('do less time') from an existing plea deal in May 2008.
The original plea deal was for 2 years, but had been reduced to 18 months, which the email author states was already 'a big break'.
The prosecution had identified more victims since agreeing to the 18-month deal.
Senior officials ('Wand and Alex') had directed that the office was 'not negotiating with this guy any more in any way'.
The email chain shows internal coordination and decision-making within the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the Epstein case.
